title: 107_s3040
content: The Act may be cited as the "Taunton, Massachusetts Study Act" and includes findings. Congress finds that the city of Taunton, Massachusetts has 9 historic districts, including the Church Green, Courthouse, Taunton Green, and Reed and Barton districts, with over 600 properties on the National Register of Historic Places. Taunton Green is significant as the site where the Sons of Liberty raised the Liberty and Union Flag in 1774, sparking the movement leading to the American Revolution. Taunton played a significant role in the American Revolution, with citizens volunteering for service in subsequent wars. Robert Treat Paine, a resident, was the first Attorney General of Massachusetts and a signer of the Declaration of Independence. The city was a leader in the Industrial Revolution, known for innovations in silver and paper manufacturing, as well as shipbuilding. Frederick Law Olmsted designed the landscaping of the Courthouse Green. The Courthouse Green was designed by Frederick Law Olmsted, who also prepared landscaping plans for other historical areas in Taunton. Main Street features significant 19th-century architecture like Taunton City Hall and the Leonard Block building. The city has preserved artifacts, gravesites, and documents dating back to its founding in 1638. Taunton has a rich history and continues to be an important city. Taunton, an important destination for immigrants, contributes to the unique ethnic character of Southeastern Massachusetts. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines "city" as Taunton, Massachusetts, "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior, and "State" as Massachusetts. The Secretary will conduct a study with State historic preservation officers to determine if certain historic buildings in Taunton can be designated as part of the National Park System. The study must follow specific requirements and analyze whether the historic areas can be managed by the National Park Service or an alternative structure. The curr_chunk discusses the criteria for areas to be designated as part of the National Park System, emphasizing the importance of cultural, historic, and natural resources that represent the heritage of the United States. It also highlights the need for outstanding opportunities for conservation, recreation, and education within these areas. These designated areas should reflect traditions, customs, beliefs, and historical events significant to the United States. The curr_chunk discusses managing (E) by the National Park Service in partnership with various entities as part of the National Park System, aligning with local economic activity. The Secretary is required to submit a report to specific committees regarding the findings, conclusions, and recommendations of a study conducted under this Act. Additionally, there is an authorization of appropriations for the Act.
